content: How can I help you today?

Well, I guess I need some help figuring things out. My wife and I have been struggling a lot at home, mostly because of our younger son. He's been acting out, and we have no idea how to help him. It’s affecting everything—our marriage, my focus at work, and even my relationship with my daughter.

That sounds incredibly tough—like so many parts of your life are being pulled in different directions. You're managing a lot right now: your son's behavior, your marriage, your work, and your connection with your daughter. It can feel overwhelming when things are all tied together like this. What’s been the most challenging part for you?

I’d say the most challenging part is feeling stuck—like no matter what I do, it’s not helping. My son’s behavior just keeps getting worse, and my wife and I are constantly arguing about how to handle it. I’m losing my focus and patience, and I feel like I’m failing everyone in my family.

It sounds like you're carrying a heavy weight, feeling the pressure to hold everything together while nothing seems to improve. Balancing those emotions of wanting to help your son, support your wife, and stay patient through it all sounds exhausting. What have you been hoping for, or wishing could change, amidst all of this?

I just wish things could feel normal again, you know? I wish I could find a way to help my son so he’s happy and not acting out all the time, and then maybe my wife and I could stop blaming each other for everything. I just want my family to feel okay and to stop feeling so disconnected from everyone.

You’re really longing for that sense of connection and stability within your family—a way to bring everyone back together and find some peace. It’s clear how much you care about your family and want things to get better. What kinds of things have you already tried to help improve the situation?

We’ve tried talking to our son, setting boundaries, changing our routines—nothing seems to stick. My wife and I even tried talking to each other more about what to do, but it always turns into an argument. It feels like we’re both just too stressed to come up with solutions that work.

It sounds like you’ve really put in a lot of effort—trying to communicate with your son, adjust routines, and work through it as a team with your wife. Even though it hasn’t led to the changes you’re hoping for yet, it shows just how invested you are in doing what’s best for your family. What do you think has been getting in the way, especially when you and your wife try working together on this?

I think it’s the frustration and stress we’re both carrying. We’re on edge all the time, and instead of working together, it feels like we’re stuck in this blame game. We end up pointing fingers at each other rather than focusing on what’s really going on with our son.

It sounds like the stress and frustration make it so much harder to connect and support each other as a team. And with those emotions running high, it’s been easier to get stuck on blaming rather than finding solutions together. What do you think might help create more space for you both to shift away from that pattern?

I’m honestly not sure. It’s hard to imagine things getting better when we’re both so overwhelmed all the time. Maybe if we could communicate without it turning into an argument, that would be a start. But I have no idea how to even get to that point.

It’s clear you want to break that cycle and find a way to communicate without the tension taking over. Even though it feels uncertain right now, recognizing the need for better communication and hoping to take that step is meaningful. What do you think would be different if you and your wife were able to communicate in a calmer, more productive way?

I think it would help us feel more like a team again, instead of being at odds with each other. Maybe we could actually focus on helping our son instead of getting stuck in arguments. It would take some weight off, and maybe I’d feel less like I’m failing everyone.

It sounds like finding a way to communicate calmly could make such a difference—not only in how you and your wife work together for your son but also in how you feel about yourself and your role in the family. It’s clear how much you’re invested in making things better for everyone. What’s one small step you feel ready to take to start moving toward that sense of teamwork you’re hoping for?
I don’t really know what that step would be, to be honest. I guess I could try to talk to my wife more calmly, but it’s really hard when everything feels so tense. I don’t even know if it would work.

Taking that step to have calmer conversations feels like it could be a big challenge with so much tension between you both. And yet, it sounds like you’re open to trying, even if there's uncertainty around it. That willingness is important. What do you think might make it easier for you to approach those conversations differently, even when emotions are running high?

Maybe if we could set aside a specific time to talk, when things aren’t already heated, that might help. Or maybe we need some kind of outside help, like having someone guide the conversations, but I’m not sure where to even begin with that. It’s just so overwhelming.

That’s a thoughtful idea—setting aside time when emotions aren’t so high might give you both a chance to focus more calmly. And it sounds like you’re also thinking about reaching out for guidance or support to navigate these conversations together, which shows a lot of insight into the challenges you’re facing. Would it help to explore what kind of support might work best for you and your wife right now?
I think I’m okay to end the conversation for now. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
